Sparse Random Networks for
Communication-Efficient Federated Learning

Berivan IsikÂ¶ , Â Francesco PaseÂ§âˆ—, Â Deniz Gunduzâ€¡, Â  Tsachy WeissmanÂ¶, Â  Michele ZorziÂ§
Â¶Stanford University, Â§University of Padova, â€¡Imperial College London
berivan.isik@stanford.edu, pasefrance@dei.unipd.it First two authors contributed equally. Work done while F.P. was visiting Imperial College London.
Abstract

One main challenge in federated learning is the large communication cost of exchanging weight updates from clients to the server at each round. While prior work has made great progress in compressing the weight updates through gradient compression methods, we propose a radically different approach that does not update the weights at all. Instead, our method freezes the weights at their initial random values and learns how to sparsify the random network for the best performance. To this end, the clients collaborate in training a stochastic binary mask to find the optimal sparse random network within the original one. At the end of the training, the final model is a sparse network with random weights â€“ or a subnetwork inside the dense random network. We show improvements in accuracy, communication (less than 111 bit per parameter (bpp)), convergence speed, and final model size (less than 111 bpp) over relevant baselines on MNIST, EMNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100 datasets, in the low bitrate regime.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed learning framework where clients collaboratively train a model by performing local training on their data and by sharing their local updates with a server every few iterations, which in turn aggregates the local updates to create a global model, that is then transmitted to the clients for the next round of training. While being an appealing approach for enabling model training without the need to collect client data at the server, uplink communication of local updates is a significant bottleneck in FL (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021). This has motivated research in communication-efficient FL strategies (McMahan etÂ al., 2017a) and various gradient compression schemes via sparsification (Lin etÂ al., 2018; Wang etÂ al., 2018; Barnes etÂ al., 2020; Ozfatura etÂ al., 2021; Isik etÂ al., 2022), quantization (Alistarh etÂ al., 2017; Wen etÂ al., 2017; Bernstein etÂ al., 2018; Mitchell etÂ al., 2022), and low-rank approximation (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016; Vargaftik etÂ al., 2021; 2022; Basat etÂ al., 2022). In this work, while aiming for communication efficiency in FL, we take a radically different approach from prior work, and propose a strategy that does not require communication of weight updates. To be more precise, instead of training the weights,

(1) the server initializes a dense random network with dğ‘‘d weights, denoted by the weight vector ğ’˜init=(w1init,w2init,â€¦,wdinit)superscriptğ’˜initsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤init1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤init2â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤initğ‘‘\bm{w^{\text{init}}}=(w^{\text{init}}_{1},w^{\text{init}}_{2},\dots,w^{\text{init}}_{d}), using a random seed ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–¤ğ–£ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–¤ğ–£\mathsf{SEED}, and broadcasts ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–¤ğ–£ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–¤ğ–£\mathsf{SEED} to the clients enabling them to reproduce the same ğ’˜initsuperscriptğ’˜init\bm{w^{\text{init}}} locally,

(2) both the server and the clients keep the weights frozen at their initial values ğ’˜initsuperscriptğ’˜init\bm{w^{\text{init}}} at all times,

(3) clients collaboratively train a probability mask of dğ‘‘d parameters ğœ½=(Î¸1,Î¸2,â€¦,Î¸d)âˆˆ[0,1]dğœ½subscriptğœƒ1subscriptğœƒ2â€¦subscriptğœƒğ‘‘superscript01ğ‘‘\bm{\theta}=(\theta_{1},\theta_{2},\dots,\theta_{d})\in[0,1]^{d},

(4) the server samples a binary mask from the trained probability mask and generates a sparse network with random weights â€“ or a subnetwork inside the initial dense random network as follows

ğ’˜final=Bernâ€‹(ğœ½)âŠ™ğ’˜init,superscriptğ’˜finaldirect-productBernğœ½superscriptğ’˜init\bm{w^{\text{final}}}=\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta})\odot\bm{w^{\text{init}}}, (1)

where Bernâ€‹(â‹…)Bernâ‹…\text{Bern}(\cdot) is the Bernoulli sampling operation and âŠ™direct-product\odot the element-wise multiplication.

We call the proposed framework Federated Probabilistic Mask Training (ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}) and summarize it in FigureÂ 1. At first glance, it may seem surprising that there exist subnetworks inside randomly initialized networks that could perform well without ever modifying the weight values. This phenomenon has been explored to some extent in prior work (Zhou etÂ al., 2019; Ramanujan etÂ al., 2020; Pensia etÂ al., 2020; Diffenderfer & Kailkhura, 2020; Aladago & Torresani, 2021) with different strategies for finding the subnetworks. However, how to find these subnetworks in a FL setting has not attracted much attention so far. Some exceptions to this are works by Li etÂ al. (2021); Vallapuram etÂ al. (2022); Mozaffari etÂ al. (2021), which provide improvements in other FL challenges, such as personalization and poisoning attacks, while not being competitive with existing (dense) compression methods such as QSGDÂ (Alistarh etÂ al., 2017), DRIVEÂ (Vargaftik etÂ al., 2021), and SignSGDÂ (Bernstein etÂ al., 2018) in terms of accuracy under the same communication budget. In this work, we propose a stochastic way of finding such subnetworks while reaching higher accuracy at a reduced communication cost â€“ less than 1 bit per parameter (bpp).

In addition to the accuracy and communication gains, our framework also provides an efficient representation of the final model post-training by requiring less than 1 bpp to represent (i) the random seed that generates the initial weights ğ’˜initsuperscriptğ’˜init\bm{w^{\text{init}}}, and (ii) a sampled binary vector Bernâ€‹(ğœ½)Bernğœ½\text{Bern}(\bm{\theta}) (computed with the trained ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}). Therefore, the final model enjoys a memory-efficient deployment â€“ a crucial feature for machine learning at power-constrained edge devices. Another advantage our framework brings is the privacy amplification under some settings, thanks to the stochastic nature of our training strategy.

Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

(1) We propose a FL framework, in which the clients do not train the model weights, but instead a stochastic binary mask to be used in sparsifying the dense network with random weights. This differs from the standard training approaches in the literature.

(2) Our framework provides efficient communication from clients to the server by requiring (less than) 111 bpp per client while yielding faster convergence and higher accuracy than the baselines.

(3) We propose a Bayesian aggregation strategy at the server side to better deal with partial client participation and non-IID data splits.

(4) The final model (a sparse network with random weights) can be efficiently represented with a random seed and a binary mask which requires (less than) 1 bpp â€“ at least 32Ã—32\times more efficient storage and communication of the final model with respect to standard FL strategies.

(5) We demonstrate the efficacy of our strategy on MNIST, EMNSIT, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100 datasets under both IID and non-IID data splits; and show improvements in accuracy, bitrate, convergence speed, and final model size over relevant baselines, under various system configurations.

2 Related Work

In this section, we briefly discuss the related work in (1) communication-efficient FL, (2) pruning for FL, and (3) finding subnetworks in a random network.

Communication-Efficient FL.

One way of improving communication efficiency in FL is to compress the model updates using gradient compression methods like sparsification (Aji & Heafield, 2017; Lin etÂ al., 2018; Wang etÂ al., 2018; Barnes etÂ al., 2020; Ozfatura etÂ al., 2021; Isik etÂ al., 2022), quantization (Alistarh etÂ al., 2017; Wen etÂ al., 2017; Suresh etÂ al., 2017; Bernstein etÂ al., 2018; Mitchell etÂ al., 2022), and low-rank approximation (Wang etÂ al., 2018; Vogels etÂ al., 2019; Vargaftik etÂ al., 2021; 2022; Mohtashami etÂ al., 2022; Basat etÂ al., 2022); or more FL-oriented compression schemes such as (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016; McMahan etÂ al., 2017a; Sattler etÂ al., 2019; Rothchild etÂ al., 2020; Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2020; Haddadpour etÂ al., 2020; 2021), while training a dense network. Our framework differs from these dense compression methods substantially due to the unconventional stochastic mask training strategy; however, we take SignSGD (Bernstein etÂ al., 2018), TernGrad (Wen etÂ al., 2017), QSGD (Alistarh etÂ al., 2017), DRIVE (Vargaftik etÂ al., 2021), and EDEN (Vargaftik etÂ al., 2022) as our baselines since they work in the same bitrate regime as ours (â‰ˆ\approx1 bpp).

Pruning for FL.

Since the introduction of the Lottery Ticket Hypothesis (LTH)Â (Frankle & Carbin, 2018), there has been growing interest in finding sparse and trainable networks at initialization. The main hypothesis in this line of work is that there exist sparse networks (lottery tickets) inside randomly initialized dense networks such that those sparse networks can be trained to a surprisingly good performance. In the original paper, the strategy for finding these lottery tickets is to iteratively train the dense network, i.e., finding the lottery tickets is expensive. We distinguish our approach from the FL papers that utilize the LTH (Li etÂ al., 2020; Ji etÂ al., 2020; Seo etÂ al., 2021) and pruning (Lin etÂ al., 2020; Munir etÂ al., 2021; Yu etÂ al., 2021; Liu etÂ al., 2021; Jiang etÂ al., 2022; Babakniya etÂ al., 2022; Dai etÂ al., 2022; Lin etÂ al., 2020; Bibikar etÂ al., 2022) for three mains reasons: (i) These methods require training the weight values, and thus cannot provide an efficient representation of the final model as ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} does. Recall that we achieve at least 32Ã—32\times more efficient storage and communication of the final model by representing it with just a random seed and a binary mask. (ii) Some of these works require finding the lottery tickets prior to FL trainingÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020). While this could improve the communication cost during the FL training since they communicate sparse networks, it increases the computation cost significantly due to the burden of finding lottery tickets via training. (iii) As opposed to the LTH- or pruning-based FL works, our framework learns with what probability a particular weight should stay in the final model, i.e., the final sparsity level is also a learned parameter optimized for the best performance. Overall, since ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} is not in the same bitrate regime as these works (they require higher bitrates to communicate continuous weight values), we do not compare against them.

Finding Subnetworks Inside a Random Network.

Our work is closest to recent works of Zhou etÂ al. (2019); Ramanujan etÂ al. (2020); Pensia etÂ al. (2020); Aladago & Torresani (2021), which find subnetworks (or supermasks) inside a dense network with random weights that perform surprisingly well without ever training the weights, but in a centralized scenario. In this work, we take advantage of the existence of such subnetworks to reduce the communication budget in FL to less than 1 bpp with faster convergence and higher accuracy than our relevant baselines in the same bitrate regime, while further compressing the final model, all simultaneously. Prior works (Li etÂ al., 2021; Vallapuram etÂ al., 2022; Mozaffari etÂ al., 2021) also consider finding subnetworks inside a dense random network in a FL setting, but they differ from our approach on several levels. For instance, they focus on different challenges in FL, such as personalization and poisoning attacks, which limits their ability to improve over existing compression methods in accuracy-communication bitrate tradeoff. One fundamental reason for this is their deterministic mask training strategy, which involves hard thresholding or sign operations. On the other hand, the stochasticity in ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} allows us to (i) enjoy a better accuracy-communication cost tradeoff, (ii) have an unbiased estimate of the true aggregate of the local masks with a provable upper bound on the error, (iii) design an improved aggregation strategy with a Bayesian approach so that the previous masks at the server are not hard replaced â€“ a useful strategy specifically in unbalanced non-IID splits, and (iv) gain privacy benefits via amplification in the Bernoulli sampling step. To demonstrate these benefits over deterministic schemes, we compare our method against FedMaskÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021) by adapting it slightly to mainly focus on communication efficiency, rather than personalization, and to improve its accuracy-communication efficiency performance. More specifically, we discard the initial pruning stage that was deployed for personalization. This change was necessary because (a) this paper does not study personalization, so this pruning step would put FedMask at a disadvantage in our experimental setup, and (b) the initial pruning step requires extra training at client devices, which is computationally more expensive than ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} and the dense baselines.

3 Federated Probabilistic Mask Training (ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM})

We first describe the simpler version of the ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} framework in SectionÂ 3.1, which provides an unbiased estimation of the mean of the learned probability masks at the server with bounded error. Next, we propose a modification in our aggregation strategy by exploiting the underlying Bernoulli mechanism in SectionÂ 3.2. This helps boost the performance of ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} in the case of partial client participation. We then discuss the details of the distribution of the initial weights in SectionÂ 3.3, and finally describe the privacy benefits of ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} in SectionÂ 3.4. We use capital letters for random variables, small letters for their realization and deterministic quantities, and bold letters for vectors. All the local operations from Step 2 to Step 4 are differentiable, except for the Bernoulli sampling. We backpropagate the gradients through the Bernoulli sampling operation with a straight-through estimator Bengio etÂ al. (2013), using the first-order gradient of the Bernoulli function, which is simply equal to the probability mask ğœ½k,tsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{\theta}^{k,t}.

Since each client communicates a stochastic binary mask ğ‘´k,tsuperscriptğ‘´ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{M}^{k,t}, 1 bpp is the worst-case bitrate for ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}. We can further reduce the bitrate to less than 1 by using arithmetic coding (Rissanen & Langdon, 1979) or universal coding (Krichevsky & Trofimov, 1981; Barron etÂ al., 1998) to encode ğ’k,tsuperscriptğ’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{m}^{k,t}, and achieve the empirical entropy since dğ‘‘d is large. This gives us smaller bitrates whenever the frequency of 1â€™s in ğ’k,tsuperscriptğ’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{m}^{k,t} is far from 0.5 â€“ which is usually the case for our method (see FigureÂ 3 and AppendixÂ E.2 for results). We note that, with a deterministic mask training approach as in FedMask (Li etÂ al., 2021), arithmetic coding of ğ’k,tsuperscriptğ’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{m}^{k,t}s does not provide any further gain in bitrate, as we have empirically observed that the frequency of 1â€™s is always around 0.5 (see FigureÂ 3 and AppendixÂ E.2) â€“ here we apply arithmetic coding for FedMask to improve our baseline although it was not proposed in the original paper. Moreover, FedMask (Li etÂ al., 2021) and HideNSeek (Vallapuram etÂ al., 2022) do not enjoy the guarantees we have as their estimator (i) is not unbiased and (ii) does not have an upper bound on the estimation error due to hard thresholding (Li etÂ al., 2021) and sign operations (Vallapuram etÂ al., 2022). This is another benefit of our stochastic sampling approach.

3.2 ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} with Bayesian Aggregation

Another important aspect that differentiates our work from existing masking methods such as FedMaskÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021) and HideNSeekÂ (Vallapuram etÂ al., 2022) is the Bayesian aggregation strategy, which exploits the underlying stochastic mask to synthesize a global model, boosting the performance in scenarios where only a fraction of the clients participate in each round. Given the probabilistic interpretation of the ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} maskâ€™s values, at the server side we further model the probability mask ğœ½g,tsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘”ğ‘¡\bm{\theta}^{g,t} with a Beta distribution Betaâ€‹(ğœ¶g,t,ğœ·g,t)Betasuperscriptğœ¶ğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğœ·ğ‘”ğ‘¡\text{Beta}(\bm{\alpha}^{g,t},\bm{\beta}^{g,t}), parameterized by the round-dependent parameters ğœ¶g,tsuperscriptğœ¶ğ‘”ğ‘¡\bm{\alpha}^{g,t} and ğœ·g,tsuperscriptğœ·ğ‘”ğ‘¡\bm{\beta}^{g,t}, which are initialized to ğœ¶g,0=ğœ·g,0=ğ€ğŸsuperscriptğœ¶ğ‘”0superscriptğœ·ğ‘”0subscriptğ€0\bm{\alpha}^{g,0}=\bm{\beta}^{g,0}=\bm{\lambda_{0}}. At the beginning of the training process, there is no prior knowledge indicating which network weight should be more important than the others, and so each entry in the probability mask is uniformly distributed in [0,1]01[0,1] â€“ which is the prior distribution. Consequently, the clientsâ€™ local binary masks ğ‘´k,tsuperscriptğ‘´ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{M}^{k,t}s are the data the server uses to update its belief on each weight score, and so the aggregation strategy corresponds now to a posterior update. Specifically, given the conjugate relation between the Beta-Bernoulli distributions, the new posteriors are still Beta distributions with parameters

ğœ¶g,t=ğœ¶g,tâˆ’1+ğ‘´agg,tandğœ·g,t=ğœ·g,tâˆ’1+Kâ‹…ğŸâˆ’ğ‘´agg,tâˆ€tâ‰¥1,formulae-sequencesuperscriptğœ¶ğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğœ¶ğ‘”ğ‘¡1superscriptğ‘´aggğ‘¡andformulae-sequencesuperscriptğœ·ğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğœ·ğ‘”ğ‘¡1â‹…ğ¾1superscriptğ‘´aggğ‘¡for-allğ‘¡1\displaystyle\bm{\alpha}^{g,t}=\bm{\alpha}^{g,t-1}+\bm{M}^{\text{agg},t}\quad\text{and}\quad\bm{\beta}^{g,t}=\bm{\beta}^{g,t-1}+K\cdot\bm{1}-\bm{M}^{\text{agg},t}\quad\forall t\geq 1, (3)

where ğ‘´agg,t=âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦tğ‘´k,tsuperscriptğ‘´aggğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ’¦ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘´ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{M}^{\text{agg},t}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{t}}\bm{M}^{k,t}, and ğŸ1\bm{1} is the dğ‘‘d-dimensional all-ones vector. Then, the server broadcasts to the clients the mode of the Bernoulli distributions, as suggested by Ferreira etÂ al. (2021),

ğœ½g,t=ğœ¶g,tâˆ’1ğœ¶g,t+ğœ·g,tâˆ’2,superscriptğœ½ğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğœ¶ğ‘”ğ‘¡1superscriptğœ¶ğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğœ·ğ‘”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\bm{\theta}^{g,t}=\frac{\bm{\alpha}^{g,t}-1}{\bm{\alpha}^{g,t}+\bm{\beta}^{g,t}-2}, (4)

where the division operation is applied element-wise. However, to obtain the best performance out of this method, the Beta parameters should be re-initialized to their original values ğ€0subscriptğ€0\bm{\lambda}_{0} with some regularity. We present an ablation study to demonstrate the improvements gained by the Bayesian aggregation strategy and the reasonable choices for the resetting frequency in SectionÂ 4.3. Notice that if ğ€0=ğŸsubscriptğ€01\bm{\lambda}_{0}=\bm{1}, and if ğœ¶ğœ¶\bm{\alpha} and ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta} are re-initialized at the beginning of each round, the method is equivalent to the aggregation strategy detailed in SectionÂ 3.1.2.

3.3 Weight Distribution

As mentioned in SectionÂ 3.1, the fixed weight vector ğ’˜initsuperscriptğ’˜init\bm{w}^{\text{init}} is initialized by sampling from the distribution Pwsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¤P_{w} using the randomly generated ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–¤ğ–£ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–¤ğ–£\mathsf{SEED}. We note that the choice of this distribution impacts two important aspects of ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}: (i) the values of ğ’˜initsuperscriptğ’˜init\bm{w}^{\text{init}} highly influence the final accuracy achieved by the model, as they represent the building blocks to extract a subnetwork fğ’˜Ë™subscriptğ‘“Ë™ğ’˜f_{\dot{\bm{w}}} (see FigureÂ 1), which should be rich enough to solve the learning task, and (ii) the size of the sample space of Pwsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘¤P_{w} affects the number of bits needed to store the model during the inference process (this is different from the 1 bpp model storage when the model is not in use). Regarding (i), as also proposed in Ramanujan etÂ al. (2020), we sample weights from a uniform distribution, whose domain is {âˆ’Ïƒ,+Ïƒ}ğœğœ\{-\sigma,+\sigma\}, where Ïƒğœ\sigma is the standard deviation of the Kaiming Normal distribution (He etÂ al., 2015). In this way, we control the variance of the neuronsâ€™ output to be âˆ¼1similar-toabsent1\sim 1, which avoids the vanishing or the explosion of activation values. Previous experiments in (Zhou etÂ al., 2019; Ramanujan etÂ al., 2020) also demonstrate the superior performance achieved by binary weights distributions when compared to standard continuous counterparts, e.g., Gaussian. Regarding (ii), even if knowing the value of ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–¤ğ–£ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–¤ğ–£\mathsf{SEED} is enough to perfectly reconstruct the vector ğ’˜initsuperscriptğ’˜init\bm{w}^{\text{init}}, one would have to generate the entire vector at every inference step. Consequently, to achieve fast inference, the actual values of the weights need to be stored in the memory of the devices during the inference process. Fortunately, our initialization allows for efficient storage even during inference since (after reconstructing ğ’˜finalsuperscriptğ’˜final\bm{w}^{\text{final}} using ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–¤ğ–£ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–¤ğ–£\mathsf{SEED} and ğ’finalâˆˆ{0,1}dsuperscriptğ’finalsuperscript01ğ‘‘\bm{m}^{\text{final}}\in\{0,1\}^{d}) we only need to indicate whether the weight values in ğ’˜finalsuperscriptğ’˜final\bm{w}^{\text{final}} are âˆ’Ïƒğœ-\sigma, 00, or +Ïƒğœ+\sigma, with a ternary representation that can be efficiently deployed on hardware (Alemdar etÂ al., 2017).

3.4 Privacy

Privacy is another challenge in FL as the model updates (in our case, ğ‘´k,tsuperscriptğ‘´ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{M}^{k,t}s) may leak information about the client data. In AppendixÂ C, we analyze the differential privacy guarantees of ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} and give an initial foray into how ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} can be helpful in amplifying privacy.

4 Experiments

In this section, we empirically show the performance of ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} in terms of accuracy, bitrate, converge speed, and the final model size. We consider four datasets: CIFAR-10 with 10 classes, CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) with 100 classes, MNIST (Deng, 2012) with 10 classes, and EMNIST (Cohen etÂ al., 2017) with 47 classes. For CIFAR-100, we use a 10-layer convolutional network (CNN) ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…\mathtt{CONV}-ğŸ·ğŸ¶10\mathtt{10} and ResNet-18Â He etÂ al. (2016); for CIFAR-10, a 6-layer CNN ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…\mathtt{CONV}-ğŸ¼6\mathtt{6} and ResNet-18Â He etÂ al. (2016); and for MNIST and EMNIST, a 4-layer CNN ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…\mathtt{CONV}-ğŸº4\mathtt{4}. A detailed description of the architectures can be found in AppendixÂ D. Due to limited space, we provide the results on ResNet-18 in AppendixÂ E.1. We first compare ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} with SignSGDÂ (Bernstein etÂ al., 2018), TernGradÂ (Wen etÂ al., 2017), QSGDÂ (Alistarh etÂ al., 2017), DRIVEÂ (Vargaftik etÂ al., 2021), EDENÂ (Vargaftik etÂ al., 2022), and FedMaskÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021) on IID data split and full client participation in SectionÂ 4.1. We then extend our experiments to non-IID data splits and partial participation in SectionÂ 4.2. Finally, in SectionÂ 4.3, we present a key ablation study to justify why the Bayesian aggregation strategy is necessary for partial participation and to demonstrate how the resetting frequency affects the convergence rate and the final accuracy. Clients perform 3 local epochs in all experiments. We provide additional details on the experimental setup in AppendixÂ D. We present results averaged over 3 runs.

4.1 IID Data Split and Full Participation (K=Nğ¾ğ‘K=N)

In this section, we focus on IID data distribution and the case when all the clients participate in the training at each round. We set the number of clients to N=K=10ğ‘ğ¾10N=K=10. We report the estimated bitrate for the arithmetic code that uses the empirical frequency of the symbols (for our method ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}, this corresponds to the frequency of 1â€™s in ğ’k,tsuperscriptğ’ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{m}^{k,t}) â€“ which is equal to the empirical entropy for blocklength dğ‘‘d as large as the model size. In FigureÂ 3, we compare the accuracy, bitrate, and convergence speed of ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} with relevant baselines. As can be seen in the figure, ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} converges to the highest accuracy on all four datasets. DRIVE, EDEN, and QSGD (they mostly overlap in the accuracy plots) seem to be the three baselines that perform the best after ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}; however, their convergence speed is significantly lower than ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}. In terms of convergence speed, FedMask is the fastest among the baselines â€“ in fact, at the beginning of the training, FedMask is faster than ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} as well. However, its final accuracy is lower than the others. We also would like to highlight that while some of our baselines, such as FedMask and TernGrad, have a visibly high variance in accuracy, ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} shows stable training behavior across all experiments.

In terms of bitrate, SignSGD and FedMask consistently spend 1 bpp, which is the default number when a binary mask or sign mask is communicated. This means binary values (1â€™s and 0â€™s) are almost equally distributed in their masks, which prevents them from enjoying additional bitrate gains. Across all experiments, TernGrad has the highest bitrate. We would like to leave a note about the bitrate of QSGD. Unlike other baselines, including our work, QSGD can go down to very low bitrates by adjusting the number of levels in quantization. We have observed that in the extreme quantization case, QSGD underperforms ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}. Then, we have decided to increase the number of quantization levels in QSGD to see if it improves the accuracy. However, as can be seen from the plots, even with bitrate larger than 1, QSGD still underperforms ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}. The only two baselines that challenge ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} in terms of bitrate are DRIVE and EDEN. While ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} has lower bitrates on CIFAR-10 and EMNIST; DRIVE and EDEN have better bitrates on CIFAR-100 and MNIST. However, the accuracy of DRIVE and EDEN on these datasets (specifically CIFAR-100) is significantly lower than that of ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}, with slower convergence.

As for the final model size, ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} needs only 0.8 bpp for the ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…\mathtt{CONV}-ğŸ¼6\mathtt{6} model trained on CIFAR-10, 0.85 bpp for the ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…\mathtt{CONV}-ğŸ·ğŸ¶10\mathtt{10} model trained on CIFAR-100, 0.96 bpp for the ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…\mathtt{CONV}-ğŸº4\mathtt{4} model trained on MNIST, and 0.83 bpp for the ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…\mathtt{CONV}-ğŸº4\mathtt{4} model trained on EMNIST. On the other hand, other baselines that train a dense model, namely SignSGD, TernGrad, QSGD, DRIVE, and EDEN, would need to represent each weight with their full precision value, i.e., 32 bpp. This implies that ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} provides around 38.6Ã—38.6\times improvement in the storage or the communication of the final model. Since FedMask also trains a sparse model, it enjoys a similar gain in the final model size requiring 1 bpp across all the models. Due to the stochastic masking procedure and uneven distribution of 111â€™s and 00â€™s in the binary masks, ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} has up to 0.17 bpp improvement over the deterministic procedure in FedMask, which adds up to a large gain due to the huge model size.

We provide additional experimental results with ResNet-18 model on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets in AppendixÂ E.1; and observe similar improvements over the baselines.

4.2 Non-IID Data Split and Partial Participation (K<Nğ¾ğ‘K<N)

This section considers more realistic scenarios, in which the local clientsâ€™ datasets are generated from slightly different data distributions. We focus on CIFAR-10 with ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…ğ™²ğ™¾ğ™½ğš…\mathtt{CONV}-ğŸ¼6\mathtt{6}, and we compare ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} against (i) the most promising baselines, which, based on the results of SectionÂ 4.1, are DRIVE, EDEN, and QSGD, and (ii) FedMask, as it is the only sparse baseline. To choose the size of each dataset |ğ’Ÿn|=Dnsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘›subscriptğ·ğ‘›|\mathcal{D}_{n}|=D_{n}, for each client nâˆˆ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘›1â€¦ğ‘n\in\{1,\dots,N\}, an integer jnsubscriptğ‘—ğ‘›j_{n} is sampled uniformly from {10,11,â€¦,100}1011â€¦100\{10,11,\dots,100\}. Then, a coefficient pn=jnâˆ‘njjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘—ğ‘›subscriptğ‘›subscriptğ‘—ğ‘—p_{n}=\frac{j_{n}}{\sum_{n}j_{j}} is computed, which represents the size of the local dataset Dnsubscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{n} as a fraction of the size of the full dataset, i.e., the training set of CIFAR-10. In this way, highly unbalanced datasets can be generated from the central one. Moreover, since the task is a classification problem, we impose a maximum number of different labels, or classes, cmaxsubscriptğ‘maxc_{\text{max}}, that one client can see. Consequently, clients need cooperation to learn the statistics of other classesâ€™ distributions, as the test dataset contains samples from all classes. In addition, partial participation is also considered, meaning that at each round, the server uniformly samples a fraction Ï=KNğœŒğ¾ğ‘\rho=\frac{K}{N} of the clients to participate in the training round. This is motivated in real-world scenarios by the scarcity of physical communication network resources, which may limit the availability of part of the clients during one round. The maximum number of classes per local dataset is set to cmaxâˆˆ{2,4}subscriptğ‘max24c_{\text{max}}\in\{2,4\}, and the participation ratio is set to Ïâˆˆ{0.1,0.2,0.5,1}ğœŒ0.10.20.51\rho\in\{0.1,0.2,0.5,1\}. For Ï=1ğœŒ1\rho=1 and Ï=0.5ğœŒ0.5\rho=0.5, the total number of clients is set to N=10ğ‘10N=10 (and so Kğ¾K is equal to 101010 and 555, respectively). For Ï=0.2ğœŒ0.2\rho=0.2, we set N=100ğ‘100N=100 (and so K=20ğ¾20K=20), and for Ï=0.1ğœŒ0.1\rho=0.1, we set N=50ğ‘50N=50 (and so K=5ğ¾5K=5), which is the worst scenario among all combinations, given the small amount of information the server can collect at the end of each round. When Ï=1ğœŒ1\rho=1, for the ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} algorithm, we keep the same aggregation strategy exposed in SectionÂ 3.1.2 and FigureÂ 2; and we switch to the Bayesian aggregation method (see SectionÂ 3.2) when there is partial participation, i.e., when Ï<1ğœŒ1\rho<1. Indeed, applying the Bayesian aggregation method is revealed to be crucial for achieving good accuracy when Ï<1ğœŒ1\rho<1 and data are non-IID, obtaining a large gain with respect to the simpler version in SectionÂ 3.1.2, which resets the Beta priors at each round (or takes the average of the samples, as explained in SectionÂ 3.2). We elaborate more on this observation with an ablation study in SectionÂ 4.3. We adopt a simple heuristic schedule to reset the priors: Reset every 333 rounds when Ï=0.5ğœŒ0.5\rho=0.5 and Ï=0.2ğœŒ0.2\rho=0.2, and every 101010 rounds when Ï=0.1ğœŒ0.1\rho=0.1. As expected, the smaller the ratio ÏğœŒ\rho, the larger the number of rounds we should wait before resetting the priors to collect more information from a much more diverse pool of clients (see SectionÂ 4.3 for a rule of thumb on the resetting frequency).

TableÂ 1 reports the results with cmax=4subscriptğ‘max4c_{\text{max}}=4Â andÂ 222. ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} seems to outperform all the baselines in every configuration, as the Bayesian aggregation allows the server to collect more data before resetting the priors, which is important when clientsâ€™ data distributions are non-IID, and only a fraction of the clients participate in each round. This strategy can be seen as the ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} counterpart of decreasing the learning rate (which we applied in the other dense compression-based baselines, like DRIVE, EDEN, and QSGD). It is seen from TableÂ 1 that FedMaskÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021) is struggling in the non-IID case, as applying a hard threshold on the scores to binarize the mask does not provide a proper way to implement multiple-rounds aggregation, emphasizing the benefit of the stochastic process in ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}. It is interesting to notice that, especially when cmax=4subscriptğ‘max4c_{\text{max}}=4, the lower the value of ÏğœŒ\rho, the larger the gap between ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} and the baselines, corroborating the fact that the Bayesian strategy can better deal with partial participation. Analysis of the communication bitrate is provided in Appendix.Â E.2.

4.3 Ablation Study on the Bayesian Aggregation Strategy

In this section, we try to answer two questions: (1) Is Bayesian aggregation really necessary? and (2) What is the effect of resetting frequency on the convergence rate and the final accuracy? We do this by analyzing the effect of different resetting frequencies of the Beta priors on the training behavior of ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} with non-IID data split and partial client participation; and report the results in FigureÂ 4. Hereafter, we denote with Î³ğ›¾\gamma the number of aggregation rounds before resetting the priors. For instance, Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1 corresponds to resetting the priors at every iteration, which is equivalent to the aggregation method presented in SectionÂ 3.1.2. On the other extreme, Î³=200ğ›¾200\gamma=200 indicates that the priors are never reset. It is seen that Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1 curves fluctuate significantly and never converge to the best accuracy in any setting, while Î³=200ğ›¾200\gamma=200 curves look smoother but converge to the lowest accuracy in all settings. This intuitively makes sense because, as already mentioned in SectionÂ 3.2, by increasing the value of Î³ğ›¾\gamma, we allow the server to consider the information coming from multiple rounds while updating the global parameters. Indeed, with partial participation and non-IID data, a single roundâ€™s updates may convey skewed information, depending on the level of data heterogeneity cmaxsubscriptğ‘maxc_{\text{max}}, and client participation ratio ÏğœŒ\rho. As a rule of thumb for the resetting frequency value, we suggest tuning Î³ğ›¾\gamma around the value 1Ï1ğœŒ\frac{1}{\rho}. The rationale behind this is that with uniform client sampling, at least 1Ï1ğœŒ\frac{1}{\rho} rounds are needed to have the non-zero probability to sample from each client once before resetting the prior. In practice, we do not need to sample exactly from every client, as enough information is contained in the updates of the other sampled ones.

5 Conclusion

In this work, we introduced Federated Probabilistic Mask Training (ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}) â€“ a communication-efficient FL strategy. ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} relies on the idea of finding a sparse network in a randomly initialized dense network, which is then sparsified by a collaboratively trained stochastic binary mask. In addition to reducing the communication cost to less than 111 bit per parameter (bpp), ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} also reaches higher accuracy with faster convergence than the relevant baselines, and can potentially amplify privacy while additionally outputting a compressed final model with a size less than 1 bpp. Throughout the manuscript, we highlighted the advantages of having a stochastic mask training approach rather than a deterministic one in terms of accuracy, bitrate, and privacy.

6 Ethics Statement

All the experiments in the paper were performed on publicly available datasets. When we evaluated our strategy, we only considered accuracy as a measure of performance. However, as pointed out by Hooker etÂ al. (2020), compression methods may disproportionately impact different subgroups of the data. We agree that this may potentially create a fairness issue in all communication-efficient federated learning frameworks and deserves more attention from the community.

7 Reproduction Statement

The codebase for this work is open-sourced at https://github.com/BerivanIsik/sparse-random-networks. All the hyperparameters necessary to reproduce the results in the paper can be found in AppendixÂ D. We only used publicly available standard datasets and included links to them in the manuscript.

Appendix C Privacy Amplification and Bias Correction

Differential privacy (DP) guarantees that the probability of an outcome of an algorithm that runs on client data does not change much by a single clientâ€™s data. This is typically ensured via injecting noise to a function of the client data at a particular step in the algorithm with some utility loss in the application. While there have been many DP strategies developed for FL and deep learning (Abadi etÂ al., 2016; McMahan etÂ al., 2017b; Agarwal etÂ al., 2021; Andrew etÂ al., 2021), these strategies typically suffer from severe performance degradation due to noise injection. To make DP practical, researchers have explored certain randomization mechanisms that amplify the privacy guarantee. When these mechanisms are parts of the FL framework, such as sampling (data (Balle etÂ al., 2018; Wang etÂ al., 2019) or device (Balle etÂ al., 2020; Girgis etÂ al., 2021; Hasircioglu & Gunduz, 2022)) and shuffling (Erlingsson etÂ al., 2019; Feldman etÂ al., 2022), the amplification comes for free. This is helpful because the overall process can meet a stronger privacy guarantee without increasing the noise level. ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} promises one such amplification due to the stochastic Bernoulli sampling step. We first revisit the definitions of differential privacy (Dwork etÂ al., 2006), RÃ©nyi divergence, and RÃ©nyi differential privacy (Mironov, 2017); and then present the amplification result.

Definition 1.

[Adjacent Datasets] Two datasets D,Dâ€²âˆˆğ’ŸDsuperscriptDâ€²ğ’ŸD,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} are called adjacent if they differ in at most one data sample.

Definition 2.

[(Ïµ,Î´)ÏµÎ´\mathbf{(\epsilon,\delta)}-DP] A randomized mechanism f:ğ’Ÿâ†’â„›:fâ†’ğ’Ÿâ„›f:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} offers (Ïµ,Î´)ÏµÎ´(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy if for any adjacent D,Dâ€²âˆˆğ’ŸDsuperscriptDâ€²ğ’ŸD,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} and ğ’®âŠ‚â„›ğ’®â„›\mathcal{S}\subset\mathcal{R}

Prâ€‹[fâ€‹(D)âˆˆğ’®]â‰¤eÏµâ€‹Prâ€‹[fâ€‹(Dâ€²âˆˆğ’®)]+Î´.Prdelimited-[]ğ‘“ğ·ğ’®superscriptğ‘’italic-ÏµPrdelimited-[]ğ‘“superscriptğ·â€²ğ’®ğ›¿\displaystyle\text{Pr}[f(D)\in\mathcal{S}]\leq e^{\epsilon}\text{Pr}[f(D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{S})]+\delta.
Definition 3.

[RÃ©nyi Divergence] For two probability distributions PPP and QQQ defined over â„›â„›\mathcal{R}, the RÃ©nyi divergence of order Î±>1Î±1\alpha>1 is

DÎ±(P||Q)=1Î±âˆ’1logğ”¼xâˆ¼Q(Pâ€‹(x)Qâ€‹(x))Î±.\displaystyle D_{\alpha}(P||Q)=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log{\mathbb{E}_{x\sim Q}\left(\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}\right)^{\alpha}}.
Definition 4.

[(Î±,Ïµ)Î±Ïµ\mathbf{(\alpha,\epsilon)}-RDP] A randomized mechanism f:ğ’Ÿâ†’â„›:fâ†’ğ’Ÿâ„›f:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} offers ÏµÏµ\epsilon-RÃ©nyi differential privacy of order Î±Î±\alpha (or in short (Î±,Ïµ)Î±Ïµ(\alpha,\epsilon)-RDP) if for any adjacent D,Dâ€²âˆˆğ’ŸDsuperscriptDâ€²ğ’ŸD,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D}, it holds that

DÎ±(f(D)||f(Dâ€²))â‰¤Ïµ.\displaystyle D_{\alpha}(f(D)||f(D^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon.

Remark C.1.

Since clipping after the noise addition step would lead to bias in the estimated mean, we work out a bias correction mechanism. We use this relation to correct the bias in ğœ½Â¯^bold-^bold-Â¯ğœ½\bm{\hat{\bar{\theta}}}. In practice, to adopt the bias-correction strategy, we sample the function ğ”¼â€‹[Î¸^]ğ”¼delimited-[]^ğœƒ\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{\theta}\right], which is a function of the true parameter Î¸ğœƒ\theta, noise standard deviation Ïƒğœ\sigma, and clipping parameter cğ‘c, at Qğ‘„Q different points x1,â€¦,xQsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘„x_{1},\dots,x_{Q}, i.e., different values for the uncorrupted Î¸ğœƒ\theta, and we store the values in a table. Indeed, the values Ïƒğœ\sigma and cğ‘c are set at the beginning of the training process, secretly shared among the participants, and never modified. Then, once the server computes an estimate for Î¸^^ğœƒ\hat{\theta}, it corrects it by finding the closest outputs of ğ”¼â€‹[Î¸^]ğ”¼delimited-[]^ğœƒ\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{\theta}\right] in the stored table, and it inverts the map by choosing the corresponding xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}, i.e., the original Î¸ğœƒ\theta.

FigureÂ 6 shows the estimation error â€–ğœ½Â¯^g,tâˆ’ğœ½Â¯g,tâ€–22superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptbold-^bold-Â¯ğœ½ğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptbold-Â¯ğœ½ğ‘”ğ‘¡22||\bm{\hat{\bar{\theta}}}^{g,t}-\bm{\bar{\theta}}^{g,t}||_{2}^{2} under no noise injection case (i.e. no DP) with the black line. Recall that we want to reach a smaller estimation error and smaller Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon (i.e., a stronger privacy guarantee). The red curve corresponds to the Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon vs. estimation error behavior if Bernoulli sampling did not amplify the privacy. Appendix D Additional Experimental Details

In TableÂ 2, we provide the architectures for all the models used in our experiments. Clients performed 3 local epochs with a batch size of 128 and a local learning rate of 0.1 in all the experiments. Notice that there is no server learning rate in ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}; instead, we tune the prior resetting schedule in Bayesian aggregation for the experiments in SectionÂ 4.2. We conducted our experiments on NVIDIA Titan X GPUs on an internal cluster server, using 1 GPU per one run.

In the non-IID and partial participation experiments in SectionÂ 4.2, to distill the final model, we may apply both stochastic sampling, as during training, or a hard-threshold method, similar to the one adopted in FedMaskÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021). In the latter, a binary mask coefficient misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i} is set to 111 if Î¸i>Î±thssubscriptğœƒğ‘–subscriptğ›¼ths\theta_{i}>\alpha_{\text{ths}}, and 00 otherwise. For all experiments but one, when Î±thsâˆˆ[0.4,0.6]subscriptğ›¼ths0.40.6\alpha_{\text{ths}}\in[0.4,0.6], the thresholding test accuracy is always higher than the sampling method, and so we use the threshold method. However, in the extreme case cmax=2subscriptğ‘max2c_{\text{max}}=2 and Ï=0.1ğœŒ0.1\rho=0.1, the optimal values for Î±maxsubscriptğ›¼max\alpha_{\text{max}} were in [0.2,0.4]0.20.4[0.2,0.4] and [0.6,0.8]0.60.8[0.6,0.8] in all experiments, probably due to the high randomness given by the highly heterogeneous scenario. Consequently, for the last experiment, we just adopt the stochastic sampling strategy to evaluate the model, as further optimizing the Î±thssubscriptğ›¼ths\alpha_{\text{ths}} means adapting to the test dataset, which may corrupt the ability of the model to generalize.

Appendix E Additional Experimental Results

E.1 Additional Experiments on ResNet Architectures

In this section, we provide additional experimental results with ResNet-18 (He etÂ al., 2016) on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets. For these experiments, we focus on IID data distribution and the case when all the clients participate in the training at each round. We use the same hyperparameters from SectionÂ 4.1. We provide the details of the ResNet-18 architecture in TableÂ 3 below.

FiguresÂ 7 andÂ 8 show the results on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets, respectively. It is seen that ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} outperforms all the baselines in terms of accuracy. Although DRIVE and EDEN require approximately 0.1 smaller bitrates than ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM}, they also reach lower accuracy. In summary, the advantages of ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} discussed in the main manuscript carry over to ResNet-18 model as well.

E.2 Bitrate Considerations on non-iid Data

We now report the communication bitrate considerations on the non-IID data split experiments described in SectionÂ 4.2. TableÂ 4 reports the average bitrate needed by different algorithms over the whole training process when cmax=4subscriptğ‘max4c_{\text{max}}=4 and cmax=2subscriptğ‘max2c_{\text{max}}=2. By simply multiplying the obtained average bitrate by the total number of rounds tmax=200subscriptğ‘¡max200t_{\text{max}}=200, we obtain the total number of bits one element in the global probability mask needs to converge to its final value, indicating the total amount of information communicated during the training process.

We first observe that both DRIVE and EDEN consume almost the same amount of bits no matter the system configuration and round number (very small variance), and it is instead model dependent (see FigureÂ 3). On the contrary, ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} and QSGD report higher bitrate variability, as it depends on both the training phase and system setting. As already observed in SectionÂ 4.1, FedMask balances almost uniformly the binary updates, leading to a bitrate that is basically fixed to 111. For both cmax=4subscriptğ‘max4c_{\text{max}}=4 and cmax=2subscriptğ‘max2c_{\text{max}}=2, ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} yields the smallest bitrate when Ï=1ğœŒ1\rho=1, whereas for the other scenarios, EDEN and DRIVE are slightly more efficient. We argue that this is motivated by the fact that, as the learning task becomes harder due to the high system heterogeneity, all the models struggle to converge to good and stable solutions, which means that ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} is still uncertain about the weightsâ€™ importance probabilities ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}, setting many of them close to 0.50.50.5. However, we think that this may be a useful feature of ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} to quantify its internal uncertainty, which we will further analyze.

To conclude the analysis, we also report the ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} bpp for the final model, which is an indication of the average number of bits needed per one parameter of the model. In the case of cmax=4subscriptğ‘max4c_{\text{max}}=4, the final model sizes are 0.790.790.79 bpp, 0.8340.8340.834 bpp, and 0.990.990.99 bpp, when Ï={0.1,0.5,1}ğœŒ0.10.51\rho=\{0.1,0.5,1\}, respectively. When cmax=2subscriptğ‘max2c_{\text{max}}=2, the final model sizes are 0.80.80.8 bpp, 0.8170.8170.817 bpp, and 0.9920.9920.992 bpp. Consequently, at the end of the training process, ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼ğ™µğšğšğ™¿ğ™¼\mathtt{FedPM} remains the most efficient option, as already observed in SectionÂ 4.1.
